ratings.comment: He's a good teacher, but be prepared for difficult exams. You'll do better on exams if you spend time understanding trends (especially acid base chem), because there are usually one or two questions that can't be solved if you only memorize the mechanisms. He's helpful during office hours, and is good about answering questions during lecture.

really great at teaching the material, but gives unfair exams with material that we had not seen before/ was nearly impossible to figure out within the timeframe of the exams. for example: for exam 3 he gave us a list of 31 reactions to memorize. a 20% mechanism question had an ENTIRELY DIFFERENT MECHANISM than the literally 31 other ones provided.

Overall, good professor. His lectures are organized and he explains things very clearly. Willing to answer students' questions and help them out. Tests are tough, there's always one problem that seems to stump the majority of the class, but they definitely aren't unfair. One of my better professors here.

Professor Strieter is a great teacher. He provides clear and very organized lecture notes that really help. He explains the material very well in class. The exams are difficult (as they should be) but if you put in the time you will be fine. His office hours are very useful and I recommend attending.

Strieter was one of my favorite professors at UW. Extremely helpful in office hours, genuinely cares about students, and gives clear organized lectures. Exams are difficult but fair. Like any ochem professor, put in the time learning the material and you'll be fine. Highly recommend for those taking ochem.
Good teacher, especially at office hours.  Poor test writer.  Not bad overall, but there are better out there.

Strieter is GREAT. His notes are clear and easy to follow. Also, if youo to the review sessions you will have a pretty good idea of what to study. His exams are tough, but doable. Alicia is a great TA, don't know if she's teaching next semester too. Strieter is also really nice to look at which helps when you get overwhelmed haha

Although he explains information really well in lecture and has organized notes, the exams are not representative at all of the information given in lecture. I left the class with an A understanding of the material but because of tricks on the exams (which were only 4-5 problems each) I ended up with a B or BC. Not as great of a class as people say

Super organized lectures and everything is really clear. He thinks we all are super jazzed about ochem though, and his tests are a challenge. Although he does give a lot of hints as to what is or isn't going to be on the exam. I'd recommend him because even if you don't like ochem you at least get to look at him all class period.
Tests are far more complicated than any examples he gave in class. Discussion was mandatory and pointless. Avoid Dan at all costs.

TAKE AND STUDY THE LECTURE NOTES FOR TESTS. Don't waste your time with the book, he tests directly off lec. notes. Expect large molecules on the test, but he gives lots of exam hints as to what will be tough. Great teacher, smart, young, excited, and if you prep for tests you will be fine. Def. recomend Strieter
Great teacher. Hard Course but he is really straight forward and tries to make it easy! Study the notes that he gives during classes and go to review sessions and you will do fine.
Overall, good professor. Exams are kind of hard, but its ochem, so what can you do. I am happy to have him as a professor.

Does not have realistic expectations. Has the tendency to forget (A LOT) that this is an undergraduate level class. Can't write an exam to save his life. Exams are incredibly difficult and the pace of the class is ridiculous. I received an A in 343 and I will have to retake this class in the summer with Dr. Bowman, who is a better professor.

Really a nice guy, but to be honest he isn't a good teacher.  I am a Chem major and beat the curve of every ochem 343 test by at least 25, but his class is challenging.  He does not do a great job of tying everything back together to make it easy to learn, he primarily just spits out information and makes you learn it on your own time.  Avoid.

GREAT PROFESSOR!! He genuinely cares about his students learning the material and is an excellent lecturer.  He has a few things to learn about writing exams and his grading policies, but his curve is really generous so it's not hard to get a good grade.  Take ochem with Strieter! You wont regret it.

Lectures are clear and well organized and he recaps the previous lecture every time. Tests were pretty challenging but if you understand all mechanisms in class (there are a lot) or get lucky and happen to figure one out/remember it by chance you'll be fine. If you beat the low averages on the midterms by 10 or 15, you'll be in good shape.

He is a great lecturer and is very approachable and friendly. I enjoyed going to the lecture and hardly had to open my book all semester. Beware: the midterms (4 of them!) were a  bit frustrating. There was often not enough time to finish all of the questions in 50 mins and the molecules way more complex than seen in lecture or problem sets.

Good professor -- knows his stuff, good lecturer, nice guy.  TERRIBLE at writing tests, always too difficult with low averages...kind of defeating.  Sounds like he'll curve the class fairly well though.

One of my favorite professors at UW. Goes over everything very clearly and is more concerned with people learning and understanding the subject than grades. Good enough at explaining for me not to read the book and still get a decent grade.

If you're taking 345, you should take it with Strieter. Very helpful and gives many hints for the exam during review sessions and office hours. Class is curved extremely high, and has 3 different grading systems depending on what gives you the best grade. Attendance and book use not really necessary since all the notes are online.

Clear, organized. Doesn't know how to set up a fair grading system. Adds "extra credit" to seem like a nice guy, but doesn't understand that you can't count extra credit before doing the curve.  Uses a drop system that makes it so 1 exam doesn't count, but the exam that is dropped is just the 1 that he makes hardest, not 1 you did bad on. <50% avg.

Fantastic professor! Bullet point summary...Strieter is very organized. Recaps the previous lecture in the first ~5 minutes of class. Always willing to help. Complex but reasonable exams. Know your mechanisms! Go to class, because he writes his exams based on lecture notes.
I actually like ochem now! He is super clear and gives really good examples. Exams are tough but reasonable if you study and go to lectures.
